# Getting Started with QuartoDocBuilder.jl

QuartoDocBuilder.jl is a Julia package that generates beautiful documentation websites for your Julia packages using [Quarto](https://quarto.org/). It's inspired by R's [pkgdown](https://pkgdown.r-lib.org/) and provides similar features.

## Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure you have:

1. **Julia 1.6+** installed
2. **Quarto** installed ([download here](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/))
3. A Julia package with documented functions (docstrings)

## Installation

Add QuartoDocBuilder to your package's documentation environment:

```julia
# In your package directory
julia> using Pkg
julia> Pkg.activate("docs")
julia> Pkg.add("QuartoDocBuilder")
```

Or add it to your `docs/Project.toml`:

```toml
[deps]
QuartoDocBuilder = "164f4f01-dadb-4e86-a767-9a3bba57cbbb"
```

## Quick Start

### Step 1: Create a build script

Create a file `docs/make.jl` with:

```julia
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Build documentation with default settings
quarto_build_site(MyPackage; repo="username/MyPackage.jl")
```

### Step 2: Run the build script

```bash
julia --project=docs docs/make.jl
```

This generates the following structure:

```
docs/
├── _quarto.yml       # Quarto configuration
├── index.qmd         # Home page (from README.md)
├── reference.qmd     # API reference index
├── reference/        # Individual function docs
│   ├── my_function.qmd
│   └── ...
├── tutorials.qmd     # Tutorials index
├── tutorials/        # Tutorial files
└── styles.css        # Custom CSS
```

### Step 3: Preview locally

```bash
cd docs
quarto preview
```

This starts a local server at `http://localhost:4200` where you can see your documentation.

### Step 4: Build the final site

```bash
cd docs
quarto render
```

The rendered HTML site will be in `docs/site/` by default.

## What Gets Generated

QuartoDocBuilder automatically creates:

| Component | Source | Description |
|-----------|--------|-------------|
| **Home page** | `README.md` | Your package's README becomes the landing page |
| **Reference pages** | Docstrings | Every documented function gets its own page |
| **Reference index** | Auto-generated | Lists all functions with descriptions |
| **Tutorials** | `docs/tutorials/` | Your tutorial files (you create these) |
| **Styles** | Auto-generated | Professional CSS styling |
| **Navigation** | Auto-generated | Navbar with links to all sections |

## Adding Tutorials

Create `.qmd` files in `docs/tutorials/`:

```markdown
---
title: "My First Tutorial"
---

# Welcome

This is a tutorial for MyPackage...
```

## Publishing to GitHub Pages

### Option 1: GitHub Actions (Recommended)

Generate a workflow file:

```julia
using QuartoDocBuilder
quarto_github_action()
```

Then:

1. Push to GitHub
2. Go to Settings > Pages
3. Select "GitHub Actions" as the source

### Option 2: Manual Deployment

```bash
cd docs
quarto render
# Upload docs/site/ to your hosting
```

## Example

Here's a complete example `docs/make.jl`:

```julia
using MyPackage
using QuartoDocBuilder

# Simple usage
quarto_build_site(MyPackage;
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = "flatly"
)

# Or with full configuration
config = QuartoConfig(
    module_name = MyPackage,
    repo = "myuser/MyPackage.jl",
    theme = ThemeConfig(
        bootswatch = "flatly",
        dark_mode = true
    ),
    comments = true
)
quarto_build_site(config)
```

::: {.callout-tip}
## Pro Tip
Run `quarto_build_refpage(MyPackage)` after adding new functions to update the reference index without rebuilding everything.
:::
